comment_text: Awesome experiment!  I wish the fish tank were larger so you could see the full cavitation bubble being formed.  There's some interesting math going on there but it collapses due to the tank shattering.  Another thought experiment.  It looks like the Ruger action was able to cycle completely underwater.  If this gun were rigged up in a way to say fire while weightless and not being held, what would happen?  Obviously the bullet would shoot out, but the gun would undergo some complicated physical motion due to the center of mass rotation,  springs of the slide cocking, gasses of combustion, and the inertial frame of the pistol.  Good stuff!
i thought this was a Sirius video but you made a fake video. This is "shooting a gun under water." not a "gun underwater"

Actually, since the system operates on a pressure difference, in space, the weapon would be overgassed, as the pressure difference would be greater. So I guess it won't cycle properly, but that's easily corrected. Recoil operated firearms would function properly.
Use a blank underwater
Using a Ruger for this is very smart.  It is possible to blow up a Ruger, but you really have to work at it.  Those weapons are seriously overengineered, which I am all in favor of!
I like how the gun being underwater illustrates the shockwave of the bullet
